Link & Citation (just use the " icon on: Understanding election candidate approval ratings using social media data (http://www2013.w3c.br/companion/p189.pdf)
Data Source(s): Using the freely available twitter4j4 Java API library we collected over 37 million tweets between Sept 7, 2012 and Nov 7, 2012.
Data Analysis: 103 out of the 227 causal bigrams for Barack Obama mentioned his name while 14 causal bigrams mentioned his opponent Mitt Romney. However, 83 of the 183 causal bigrams for Mitt Romney mentioned his opponent Barack Obama, while his own name figured only 14 times in bigrams found to be causal to his approval rating.

Objective: examine perceived link between social media and public opinion
Approach: 1. qualitative analysis of media coverage referencing social media during 2010 election 2. analysis of interviews with social media researches, opinion pollsters, journalists

Ceron, Andrea, Luigi Curini, and Stefano M. Iacus.  "Using sentiment analysis to monitor electoral campaigns: Method matters—evidence from the United States and Italy." Social Science Computer Review 33.1 (2015): 3-20.

Link & Citation (just use the " icon on: Sanders, Eric, and Antal van den Bosch. "Optimising Twitter-based Political Election Prediction with Relevance andSentiment Filters." Proceedings of The 12th Language Resources and Evaluation Conference. 2020.
Social Media Analysis Comparison to Trad: sentiment filters for optimizing prediction using volume (# total) + sentiment of tweets about candidates in last few weeks of election
Contributions: demonstrated that there is no one sentiment filter ensemble that generalizes for every election (based on analyzing 2011, 2012, 2015 dutch election)
Approach: grid search for best filtering ensemble
Data Analysis: included or excluding a certain amount of tweets with a certain sentiment as training data in the model. evaluated with mean average error metric

Link & Citation (just use the " icon on: Tunggawan, Elvyna, and Yustinus Eko Soelistio.  "And the winner is…: Bayesian Twitter-based prediction on 2016 US presidential election." 2016 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA). IEEE, 2016.
Phenomena Studied: 2016 presidential Election, primaries prediction, and polls
Contributions: they showed that they got the wrong results only using positive sentiment for each candidate (they predicted ted cruz and bernie sanders...)
Approach: predicting candidates with the most positive sentiment
Data Analysis: for prediction of polls: used naive bayes model with 10-fold cross validation and got 95.8% accuracy and 0.96 F1
Technique / Methods: everything they used was "off-the-shelf" from scikit-learn

Link & Citation (just use the " icon on: Grover, Purva, et al.  "Polarization and acculturation in the 2016 US presidential election: Can Twitter analytics predict changes in voting preferences?." Technological Forecasting and Social Change (2018).
Phenomena Studied: Changes in voting preferences in 2016 presidential election
Social Media Analysis Comparison to Trad: many different social media analysis methods (detailed in data analysis)
Objective: The study aims to explore the following areas: (a) relationship between activity and engagement on social media platforms; (b) consecutive campaigns effects on popularity and engagement; (c) tweets sentiments effects on popularity and engagement; (d) relationship between drivers of voter’s choice behavior and engagement on social media platforms; (e) acculturation of ideologies through hashtags; (f) opinion polarization of users within political deliberation and the subsequently formation of communities.
Contributions: To the best of our knowledge, this study is the first within the political domain in which the social activity created by a presidential candidate’s tweets were mapped to citizens’ responses.
Approach:
Combined multiple data analysis methods (detailed in data analysis) to answer research questions: RQ1: Is the frequency of social media use related to popularity and engagement? Are the topics
discussed by Trump more popular than the topics discussed by Clinton on Twitter?
RQ2: How are the drivers of voter’s choice behaviour being discussed in the Twitter ecosystem?
How do these drivers affect the outcome of the election?
RQ3: Does acculturation have an impact on polarization? What is the nature of this polarization?
Do voters undergo transition and polarization of their preferences through Twitter over the
course of an election?
Data Analysis:
pg 15 of the pdf will full table. Broken down into 4 sections: Descriptive Analytics
, Content Analysis
, Network Analysis
, GeoSpatial Analysis
Technique / Methods: combining multiple data analysis methods to test a hypothesis and 3 research questions (detailed in data analysis and approach)

Link & Citation (just use the " icon on: Kassraie, Parnian, Alireza Modirshanechi, and Hamid K. Aghajan.  "Election Vote Share Prediction using a Sentiment-based Fusion of Twitter Data with Google Trends and Online Polls." DATA. 2017.
Phenomena Studied: Vote share prediction of 2016 us presidental election
Social Media Analysis Comparison to Trad: predicted online polls near the election, 1% error
Objective: predict online (voter sentiment of presidential candidate) polls near the 2016 US presidential election using google trends and tweets
Contributions: we bring in the novel idea of estimating candidates’ vote shares instead of directly anticipating the winner of the election, as practiced in other approaches
Approach: Four main steps are followed in this method. First, a uniformly sampled large dataset of tweets is gathered. This data is then processed and augmented by adding sentiment information to each tweet, collecting relevant keywords data from Google Trends, and arranging various online poll results. The authenticity of this data is then checked with a correlation test. In the end, a feature matrix is created and the Gaussian process regression model is trained.
Data Source(s):
Tweets, Google Trends, online Polls... these online election polls are held by
polling firms and news reports, such as HuffPost
pollster
Data Analysis: Applying this method to the US 2016 Elections resulted in predicting Clinton’s majority in the popular vote at the beginning of the elections week with 1% error
Technique / Methods: used google trends and twitter to estimate public opinion in real time then trained a Gaussian process model to predict voter share for each candidate evalauted with online polls conducted near the election
